holdings.text: Grant of dearness allowance under Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules is ex gratia and a matter of discretion for the local government, hence not justiciable and no writ of mandamus or direction can issue.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both these contentions are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be, and to the general rule that the amount of a compensatory allowance should be so regulated that the allowance is not on the whole a source of profit to the recipient, a Local Government may grant such allowance to any Government servant under its control and may make rules prescribing their amounts and the conditions under which they may be drawn. Under this provision, it is a matter of discretion with the local Government whether it will grant dearness allowance and if so, how much.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 44 confers discretionary power on local government to grant compensatory allowances without creating any enforceable right or duty on servants; distinguished from arrears of salary as debt in Punjab Province v. Tara Chand.

holdings.text: Claims to compel government to grant dearness allowance at a particular rate are matters of grace, not right, and arrears of prospective dearness allowance are not recoverable as debt unlike salary arrears.

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab Province Pandit Tara Chand was an action for recovery of arrears of salary, land it was held that under the law of this country which differed in this respect from that of England, arrears of salary were a debt due by the Government, that they could be attached in execution of a decree under section 60, Civil Procedure Code, as a debt, and that on that basis an action to recover the same was maintainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prospective DA under Rule 44 discretionary unlike accrued salary arrears which are debt attachable under CPC s.60; approved State of Bihar v. Abdul Majid.

holdings.text: A government resolution fixing scale of dearness allowance under Rule 44 constitutes 'law' as defined in Article 13(3)(a) and is subject to Article 14 scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Nambiar, the learned counsel for the respondent, did not dispute the correctness of this position. But he argued that when once the Government passed a Resolution fixing a scale of allowance under Rule 44, that would be law as defined in article 13 3 a of the Constitution, and if that law infringed, article 14, it could be declared void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concession by respondent counsel accepted; resolution exercises rulemaking power under Rule 44, falls within Art.13(3)(a) definition.

holdings.text: The scheme in the Resolution for graded dearness allowance by pay slabs with progressive reduction is not discriminatory and does not infringe Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the scheme which has been adopted in the impugned Resolution is firstly that dearness allowance if to I be paid to the employees on a scale graded according to pay, different rates being adopted for different slabs and there being a progressive reduction  of the rate from the lowest to the highest category. No contention is raised that fixing different rates of dearness allowance for different slabs of pay is obnoxious to article

holdings.reasoning_summary: Internal classification rational and uniform within slabs; no contention raised and court finds no discrimination in features of scheme.

holdings.text: Article 14 does not authorize striking down a law of one State (or Centre) by comparing it to a law of another State or the Centre on the same subject as discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 does not authorise the striking down of a law of one State on the ground that in contrast with a law of another State on the same subject its provisions are discriminatory. Nor does it contemplate a law of the Centre or of the State

holdings.reasoning_summary: Union and States distinct entities under Arts.12,13(2); Art.14 scrutiny limited to impugned law of specific state legislature; no conjunctive reading across governments.

holdings.text: The Resolution dated 16th September 1948 fixing dearness allowance scale is not repugnant to Article 14 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No internal discrimination; cannot be invalidated by comparison to Central Pay Commission recommendations as different sources of authority.

holdings.text: The Pay Committee did not partially adopt the Central Pay Commission report but applied different principles (current prices vs cost of living index, state finances considered).

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that the assumption underlying the argument of the respondent -with reference to article 14 that the Committee had adopted the Report of the Commission in part and rejected it in part was itself without foundation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of Committee report paras 80,83,31 shows independent approach different from Commission.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both these contentions are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be, and to the general rule that the amount of a compensatory allowance should be so regulated that the allowance is not on the whole a source of profit to the recipient, a Local Government may grant such allowance to any Government servant under its control and may make rules prescribing their amounts and the conditions under which they may be drawn. Under this provision, it is a matter of discretion with the local Government whether it will grant dearness allowance and if so, how much.

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab Province Pandit Tara Chand was an action for recovery of arrears of salary, land it was held that under the law of this country which differed in this respect from that of England, arrears of salary were a debt due by the Government, that they could be attached in execution of a decree under section 60, Civil Procedure Code, as a debt, and that on that basis an action to recover the same was maintainable.

In our opinion, both these companytention are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be

Mr. Nambiar, the learned counsel for the respondent, did not dispute the correctness of this position. But he argued that when once the Government passed a Resolution fixing a scale of allowance under Rule 44, that would be law as defined in article 13 3 a of the Constitution, and if that law infringed, article 14, it could be declared void.
